commentBody: It's Utahn. Not Utahan

My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Dijon-mustered "yes"?  (3)
2. Home to many kings and queens  ((7)(3)
3. How criticism of a pastry chef might be delivered?  (6)
4. Ones who should prepare for their day of reckoning?  (4)(4)
5. Big shot performer?  (5)(10)


OUI
HOLIDAY INN
TARTLY
MATH TEAM
HUMAN CANNONBALL

Coincidentally I had a sushi dinner right before doing the crossword. It involved salmon ROE and uni. I put in ROE, which was correct, but I prepared myself to get very angry if the answer was actually uni, since, despite common misconceptions, uni is not egg

This is a nifty piece of construction. In order to get the circled letters to line up vertically the constructor had to find phrases in which each circled letter is separated from the next by two letters. That’s quite impressive. 

Happy birthday, Rena. Like you, I enjoy a good vertical theme, and this one was a delight.

Happy birthday, Rena Cohen!

I won this in straight sets. Maybe that Eeyore from yesterday who was griping about LGBT clues will dig this puzzle more, right? Unless Peter Pan triggers him: he always struck me as a little gender fluid. (And I just noticed that Bobby Orr sounds like Bob Eeyore). 

"Taught to the test" was new to me, maybe that's why I graduated with a C Minus average according to the graders, and why my field experience, as recorded on my first resume, was "Washes Dishes" & "Defogs glasses." I was good at it. No boss carped about finding a morsel of egg on my plates, and if they did, I'd say "Eat it!"

Eat it. I'm going to be saying that a lot for the foreseeable future. Says who? Says me!

Happy birthday, Rena!  I really like the visual effect of this puzzle and how it evokes tennis scoring.  SETS STRAIGHT / STRAIGHT SETS.   Is the term for that a reversible phrase or something more esoteric?  I couldn’t quickly come up with others that don’t sound Yoda-esque or green painty, except HOLD ON / ON HOLD.  

Well, tomorrow, or today, depending on one’s time zone (is “zone time” a thing?), life GETS REAL again.  Time to DEFOG, get in the EN GARDE position, steel our FRAYED nerves and CHUG down some Monday.
As usual I didn’t think about the theme until the end. But then it was great fun to see!

Why does tomorrow's crossword post so early? If you go to any other games (I do Connections, Strands, and Spelling Bee), they are still today's puzzles up until quite late. 
It's 5:20 pm here in CA. I've seen the day's crossword disappear as early as 2 or 3 pm.

Our old friend EPEE makes yet another appearance, this time with a purpose! Directive? Calling?

As for Tracy’s clue suggestion for RUT, might I float an edit, into “Not/A groove”?

I’m not sure “Take the L” was the best option for EAT IT, which has previously connoted x-sports wipeouts. “Receive an L against one’s will,” maybe? Same with “Sinks in” for GETS REAL, which to me speaks more towards exhibiting frankness, as opposed to “getting” something in realization.

Thank you and Happy Birthday, Ms. Cohen!
Not every business reversal is an UPTURN, tho’ — just like EAT IT isn’t synonymous with taking an L.
My daughter completed her first NYT crossword today with no hints! I’m a proud crossword dad :] :]

"Can you help wash the dishes?"
"No, I've got a lot on my plate."

(This pun just Dawn-ed on me.)

Happy Birthday, Rena! Thank you for a fun Monday puzzle! [Groove]: https://youtu.be/Lrle0x_DHBM?si=rY2Vzm0OEG77G1HC Yes, "let's groove tonight, share the space of life..." which is so much better than thinking about the RUTs. Earth Wind & Fire music SETS a great tone for an UPTURN of any downcast mood. Aaaah, and Brian ENO is back in the house. My secret is that every time that happens, I mentally write him a love letter, welcoming him back, letting him know how much he was missed. How could I ever get tired of seeing him when he makes my puzzling life so much easier. Please don't be gone too long, Mr. ENO. You're the gift that keeps on giving. And, finally, to Sam: I didn't find ETCETC to be redundant, as you did, because i actually heard it being *said.* In writing, we would use it only once. But, in speech, it is very commonly expressed as "etcetera etcetera" as a list trails off. Just my take. A peaceful and healthy week to all!

What can I say that hasn't already been said?
I'll say it again, anyway.  Happy Birthday, Rena! May all of your presents be as delightful and satisfying as the one you have given us: 

This puzzle!  Thank you!

🎁 💐 ♥️ 🎂 🎶

That was a good Monday puzzle. I enjoyed it. Just one thing:

TAUGHT TO THE TEST looks very weird to me. Is this something people really say?

BTW, when I work with my students at university, I test what I have taught them rather than teach them to simply handle the test.
Tricky Monday.  Fun puzzle with some later in the week clues and answers imho.

How nice, on your birthday, for you to give the present to us!

Thanks for a very nice Monday puzzle!
Happy Birthday Rena Cohen. I enjoyed solving your Monday puzzle.
12D makes me think of the The King and I https://youtu.be/1JHH6iwgIek?si=8ELz9zgwfktEsmTn
So funny! When I put in the answer for 50A, I also thought about Toblerone! This is one of the rare times I instantaneously understood Sam's picture clue!

Strands thread:


Strands #358
“Step to it”
🟡🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵🔵🔵

Please advance no spoilers until after the View All Replies button.

I've been curious for a while if this game will advance to the same level as the other pastimes that have been introduced in the past few years.  Strands does not seem to be attached to my login since if I move to other computers/devices I'm presented with a new game.   

Is it still free?

Also, statistics are not being tracked.

Interesting Tuesday puzzle. All four of the theme answers were debuts, which is quite unusual for an early week puzzle. And... TAUGHTTOTHETEST was something I've never encountered before. But... everything fell together from the crosses and I ended up just a bit above my Tuesday average. Just made for a nice workout. And... had to go take a look at Ms. Cohen's previous puzzles. Her debut was also a quite unusual but really nifty construction. I don't think I could describe it but here's the Xword Info link if you want to go take a look: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=10/3/2024 Might put another puzzle find in a reply. ....
Thanks for the gift to us on your birthday, Rena.  With two grid spanning debuts, two other long debuts and a very clever construction, it made for a fun and lively Monday.
I seem to be the only one who found this difficult for a Monday.  However I don’t mind now that I know it’s Rena's birthday, and will add my good wishes.
I'm seeing a big stretch on TAUGHT TO THE TEST, but maybe that's me. Otherwise decent puzzle.

Married to a public high school teacher
required for years to 
teach TO THE TEST.

That’s a groaner in our house.

And it’s Monday.
And the world is looking gray and 
covered in slush.

Challenge to myself-
find sunshine in whatever form it may take.

Oh! Here’s one ray of light-
this crew right here!
You guys.

Thank you!
And thank you Rena!

2 minutes 34 seconds faster than my average! Loved how the answers just flowed today! I even got TAUGHT TO THE TEST without any down clues 😂 

And it's a borahae Monday with a BTS clue 💜💜 maybe I'll pull out a Love Yourself tour dvd to celebrate

Maybe it's just me!?

I completed the puzzle in good time before I even noticed there were circled letters. Thus the "theme" was lost on me. (Is that a non-sequitur?).

Has happened before. 

Cute x-word, but are "themes" really needed for Mondays' 'quickies'?

I always enjoy seeing "unit of resistance" clued, but how many times does its antiquated reciprocal show up...and in the same puzzle??

Interesting theme, but 46A was off the beaten track for me.

Lyric MORSEL heard as I did the puzzle this morning: I want you to show me what you mean Then help me with the crossword in the mornings (the rest of the song is NSFW. Lucy Dacus, Ankles.) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pcW_-uxy6dQ

Rena’s three Times puzzles have been rich with wordplay, and I, a wordplay-loving spirit, have gotten a kick out of them.  Today, I love how she bent SETS STRAIGHT into setting SET straight, vertically and horizontally.  

There were a pair of wordplay bonuses for me as well:
•	I saw how SETS STRAIGHT can become another valid phrase when you reverse the words – STRAIGHT SETS – and I wondered if there were others.  @Puzzlemucker earlier came up with the excellent HOLD ON / ON HOLD.  And here are some more: HOUSE GUEST, MAN CAVE, DOG SHOW, RAT PACK, and DRY RUN.
•	That marvelous observation by Tracy Bennet (in Sam’s blog) that RUT can be clued as {Groove] or [Not a groove].  Hah!

Just a word playground today.  On top of that, I was charmed by beauty in words: MORSEL, FRAYED, and CHUGGED.  Ahhh.

Happy birthday, dear Rena, happy birthday to you, and please, keep ‘em coming!

Happy birthday and thanks for the puzzle present.

Warning: The Toblerones you get in the US are not the same as those in Europe

Thank you again, 
Rena
Happy Birthday, Rena! Thanks for sharing your gifts with us! This puzzle was a joy to unwrap from start to finish. Thanks!
Pitch perfect Monday! (although to this former Chicagoan, Take the L has only one meaning).  Nice morning ride, Rensa...well done!
Etta James has certainly gotten a lot of mileage of "At Last."

Solved today's puzzle in 43 min flat.
Not my actual solve time of course, most of that time was spent with my head on my chest as my cat snored beside me (or was I the one snoring?)

I do not blame the crossword, it was fun and charming and clever and certainly deserved my undivided attention.... my batteries just ran out from a rough week.

On the plus side, I should have no problem beating my average Monday time for quite a while. 😄

After doing Times crosswords for awhile now, I start to imagine a world where ETTA James, Brian ENO, and BTS all work together to create an avant-garde Kpop R&B masterpiece called "Letters you need" where they sing about the Swiss ALPs and salmon ROE.
Sunny Puzzle for a sunny Virginia Monday morning. My day is made. Thank you Rena and HAPPY BIRTHDAY!

In Real Life (as opposed to CrossWorld) is Rena a Logistics Specialist?  Because getting everything SET up to fall into place exactly as needed can be quite the daunting chore....

Did Rena arrange for this morning's FOG?  

"Business reversals" are usually thought to be in the OTHER direction, are they not?

See youse guys tomorrow!
Took a while to get things going for a Monday but eventually was able to piece it together. Nice to have to work for it this early in the week!
SALLIE MAE is not a federal loan org! It’s a private loan company that makes money off of the confusion between FANNIE MAE (FNMA), an actual federal loan program.
Regarding Sam’s “fool’s spring”: https://youtu.be/wkDvqQKGgDA?si=rRDDIBT1zy67nXq8 And remember: TRUE UPS GROWON (Going to be a couple degrees above freezing here this week. But it’s a dry heat.)

Well, I was today years old when I learned that Ren, from "Ren & Stimpy" was a chihuahua. I always thought he/she/it was a  . . . well, I never knew *what* species Ren was.

Since we just recently had Lloyd Alexander, I briefly considered hEN, as in Hen Wen, the oracular pig from the Prydain Chronicles, but even Disney's dreadful *The Black Cauldron* could not turn her into anything but a pig.

I was today years old when I learned that Ren, from "Ren & Stimpy," was a chihuahua! I always thought Ren was a  . . .well, I don't know what species he/she/it was!

Since we recently had Lloyd Alexander, I briefly toyed with hEN, as in Hen Wen, the oracular pig from the Prydain Chronicles, but even Disney's dreadful version of *the Black Cauldron*  couldn't turn her into anything but a pig!

Second attempt to post: was there something objectionable, or did I forget to hit "submit"? But at least this time I won;t forget to say):

Happy Birthday, Rena!

Nice Monday puzzle. Not difficult, but not ridiculously easy. After I filled in the grid, the message appeared that there was a mistake somewhere (oops!) -- but it was easy to find. Game, SET, Match. Happy Birthday Rena Cohen!

Got "Strands" today with no hints, which is a change from all the Strands where I have needed 4 or 5 hints, and the nice puzzle program has had to show me the order of letters in a theme word.

And a late "Hurrah!" for yesterday's Mini. Vroom vroom! Let's see more Minis with surprises.

As with every Monday, I always hope to beat my best time. I quickly realized that wasn’t happening this week, finally crossing the finish line well over double my best Monday time. Some great cluing and unusual fill kept me on my toes. Especially chuckled at EAT IT, ME THREE, SAYS ME, TAUGHT TO THE TEST.

Well SET appears fours times in proper alignment, so. with the help of handy circles, we have a theme. I'd give it a CMINUS, but suppose it's OK for a Monday. ENGARDE in French and METHREE were cute, and the fill was largely devoid of proper nouns. So a nice enough puzzle, despite the underwhelming (to me) theme.

One of the most beautiful voices of R&B/Pop has left our Earthly plane... May Roberta Flack rest in peace and power. "Killing Me Softly" left an indelible mark on me when it came out in 1973. It was the year of my tenth birthday, when my family gifted me with a 3-in-1 mono sound system. Ecstatic, I plugged it in and turned on the radio, and that was the song that was playing. In honor of Ms. Flack and this puzzle's theme, here is "SET the Night to Music" – https://youtu.be/wQFIQwfxja4?si=4DBQAmPjv_q4J7Td
Happy Birthday Rena! Great puzzle from Morsal to  desert!  May your day get better and better.

I decided over the weekend that I'm going to bail out of this place. The comments here have become just too toxic. The negativity is almost as bad as the comments sections/"discussions" in places like the Boston Globe, or all of Facebook, and so on. And too often I find myself also adopting the negativity that is so common here. And then I hate myself.

I have only so much time and energy to waste paying attention to and responding to people who just want to gripe and complain. 

Besides, I have to prepare for the coming pandemic. Which is going make Covid look like a slight summer sniffle. 8^)

TATA, folks!
It’s my birthday, too! Thanks for the fun solve, Rena!

I found that a tad chewy for a Monday, but no less enjoyable.
Started well, but then came a cropper with my old friend; cultural difference. I wanted DEmist rather than FOG, no clue to Sallie MAE, or the phrases at 29A, I’m used to trip rather than EXPERIENCE and 46A, not heard that one before.
Getting the theme helped fill in the circles though. Naturally, EEYORE was a gimme.

Happy Birthday to all who celebrate today.
As a retired teacher, several leaped out at me. Despite my initial "oh my" at this for a Monday puzzle, I came close to my best. I'll call it a B+

The most do-able crossword for me for a long time. At last. I wouldn’t have known REN or BTS but didn’t need to. 
Excellent.
The correct spelling for someone from Utah is Utahn, not Utahan. The Times continually gets it wrong.
Is there a website to see how many times a clue is used? I swear I see Epee used at least once a week

Just a minor quibble as one whose job IS to prepare students for standardized exams...(in my case, nursing boards)

One can prepare students for standardized exams WITHOUT "teaching to the test" which indeed has negative connotations because it isn't truly preparing a student if all you do is teach them the exact information they need to know for the test.  But I am nitpicking.  Good puzzle overall.

And for the record, I will just call myself "a person from Utah" and avoid the whole "Utahn/Utahan" debate.
@Some guy seeing that Utahn vs Utahan is actively being debated in the Utah legislature… It’s still an open issue.
@Paul: but do they live in their own time zone?

@Cat Lady Margaret 
We do indeed live in our own time zone. Set the clock to the same time as Denver, then turn it back about 50 years!

@Some guy 

It's Utahn when there are 5 squares and Utahan when there are 6. Simple.
@Lewis Wondering why the first clue has a question mark…

@Mark -- Two reasons, I believe.  First, the pun on the word "mustered", as Dijon mustard is a common condiment.  Second, this was on a Tuesday puzzle, where when there is a question of whether or not to use the question mark, they will probably use it, to help the newer solvers.  Later in the week, they may have skipped the question mark.

Steven,

Not to worry. 
Shortz knows his sushi.


Sun Jan 10, 2021	
6D	
Sea urchin, at a sushi bar (5)	


The (5) means that exact clue has appeared five times. There have been many variants.

@john ezra  Petr plan could certainly be regarded as triggering fo that type of person if they know about the British pantomime tradition where the Principal Boy is traditionally played by a woman, Peter Pan being a prime example of such a role. And Pantomime Dames are, of course, played by men who tend to camp it up.

I've been given a subscription to the NYT puzzles as a present from some friends. It's been interesting to try the NYT crossword. I'm used to British cryptic crosswords where plays on words such as "Bread machine" are common. There were s couple of US references which I had to check up on, but RAF, Peter Pan and Eeyore were right up my street.

@Peter, I don't know if this is your first time commenting here, but welcome to this group, if it is. I can tell already from your comment that I will enjoy your take on things and hope to read more of you as the world turns. 

Michael Jackson was obsessed with Peter Pan, to the point of calling his place Neverland Ranch. I suppose he felt some affinity with Peter, the emphasis on pre-pubescent innocently gender-bending youth and on escaping the torments of childhood through fantasy and dream.
@Peter If there's ever a clue the answer for which you may think should be "right up my street,"  it will probably  be "right up my alley."  But street  does sound better!

@Peter  I didn't know that history but Peter Pan is often played by a woman here as well. Mary Martin had the role on Broadway and Cathy Rigby (or maybe some other famous gymnast?) played him in a touring show my dad took me to in El Paso TX in the mid 1970s.

@Mrs Jones yes Cathy Rigby. And before that Sandy Duncan. In opera and theatre they're known as trouser roles (or breeches, pants, or Hosenrolle). Two that spring to mind are Hansel in Hansel and Gretel, and Edwin Drood in The Mystery of Edwin Drood.

@Bob T. 

Two of the best-known are Cherubino in Le Nozze de Figaro and Octavian in Der Rosenkavalier.

@Puzzlemucker -- I grilled ChatGPT on your question about a more esoteric name for a reversible phrase, which sent it down a deep deep rabbit hole that involved many strange and wonderful terms, but none was exactly right, and so it came up dry.  But see my post (coming shortly) for some other phrases besides your excellent HOLD ON / ON HOLD.

CalGal,

By tradition -- there are some theories why -- the Sunday and Monday crosswords drop at 6 pm ET.

On the other five days the drop is at 10 pm ET.

@Barry Ancona 
What are the theories?

@CalGal 

All the other puzzles post at midnight Eastern. And the previous crossword doesn't "disappear", it just moves out of the promoted slot at the top of the screen. There is still the opportunity to solve from the archive.
@G the Spelling Bee switches at 3AM eastern time (or is it 2? I forget.)

@G 

No, the Tuesday through Saturday puzzles post at 10:00 pm ET.

@Mrs Jones 

3 am. I sometimes do it when nature calls  in the middle of the night.

@CalGal 

Maybe they post before midnight so the non-eastern time zoners don't take over the coveted early comments.

@G 
If you solve from the archive, you lose any streak you had, don't you? Not that I really care about my streaks, but I think I had 79 Mondays in a row at one point, which was just a way to see how long I've subscribed to full-access.

@CalGal 

No, as long as you solve in order, you should be fine if you don’t stray too far from the correct day. In other words, don’t expect to go away for a two-week vacation and then solve in order and keep your streak. But there’s nothing that says you can’t do it from the Archive. 

Also, though, the past week’s puzzles are posted on the main puzzle page. 

Hope this helps!

@CalGal 

An example: right now it's Monday 10:50pm Eastern. The puzzle in the main spot at the top of the Games page is for Tuesday -- but if I scroll down past the other games, an ad and the Monthly Bonus crossword, the "Last 7 Days"  of crosswords display, with the most recent (Monday) first. 

So, from there I can select the Monday grid to play, and if it's the next one in my solving experience, it will keep my streak. 

My apologies I didn't get this detailed in my original comment. I know the interface is different depending on in-app vs. browser, and phone vs. larger screens. Thus I didn't want to get too specific! 

The scenario I described is in the browser on the phone, which is where I play...

@G 

P.S. Similarly, if you're looking for the Wordplay column for a recent crossword, scroll to the bottom of the present-day column. They list a few there.

@Alfredo I had never hear the Take the L phrase. Gets Real also seemed odd to me, but I think it works because "This is getting real" does mean the speaker is understanding that something really is happening.

@Steve L 

Does taking an L mean taking a loss? Not familiar with the expression, though I filled it in correctly.

@Times Rita 

Yes, it does, and the phrase has been in the puzzle and discussed recently.

@Sean 

Congratulations to the daughter and the proud papa!
It's a wonderful milestone.
Pretty soon she'll be pulling it off on Tuesdays, too. ;-)
@Sean congratulations! I’d be pleased if my daughters got into it, too - when did she start trying to solve them?

@Sean 

Good for her and good for you!!!!
@Sean congratulations, I'm urging my son, to follow in your  daughter's footsteps. Kudos!

@Mike 

Your puns give me such Joy!

@Andrzej Yes, I've heard it. In that situation the focus is getting as many students as possible to pass the standardized test -- it's usually elementary school level, and I believe some sources of financial help require a certain percentage of students to pass-- and so the teachers end up focusing on what is needed for that test, not what the students need to be learning in general.

@Andrzej 

Yeah, that whole thing was, IMHO, part of the downfall of the American educational system.

I guess we were so tired of being beaten by other nations, so we just started cheating.  To what extent teachers knew *exactly* what to teach for the test, I don't know.  I imagine it varied.  

I could see the attitude against teaching to the test starting to slip when I retired from teaching (college) in 2000.  Some of the younger faculty didn't really see the problem with basically telling the students what was going to be tested.  I in the older guard objected to it.

@Andrzej Yes, they do say that term. My nephew teaches teachers how to teach and he has used the term. Students in high school take Regents so these students need to be able to pass those standardized exams. That's why teachers teach to the test.
@Isabeau It's high school. That's when they get the Regents.

@Andrzej Yes, they do say that term. My nephew teaches teachers how to teach and he has used the term. Students in high school take standardized tests so these students need to be able to pass those exams. That's why teachers teach to the test.

@Francis As a student, I was grateful to teachers who prepared us for those standardized tests. And the ones who did it managed to make it interesting and get in some original material as well. It doesn't have to be "either-or." Teachers can do both.

@Ms. Billie M. Spaight 

Sure, if tests are standardized it makes sense to teach to the test - especially if the teacher can also make the course interesting and useful beyond what's needed for the test itself 👍🏾

@Andrzej 

Teaching to the test is 
a negative in most ways.

Its forces educators to 
focus on disparate facts and
low-level thinking (regurgitation)
rather than higher-level
concepts and greater overall understanding.

It’s frustrating and
does a tremendous disservice 
to the students.

System is broken.
Teaching to the test is
just one of the symptoms.
@Ms. Billie M. Spaight But only in New York.

@Francis 

I remember when teaching to the test really became the priority in MA in the 90's. My mother, an English (grammar and lit courses) high school teacher, loathed it because all critical thinking was removed. The rote memorization of various state-mandated "skills" to the exclusion of other materials gave her flashbacks to her own education in the late 50's... Eventually she found a way to get in some original material, as @Ms. Billie Straight has mentioned -- making her and her students happier!

@Times Rita 

Regents are an only-in-New York phenomenon, yes!

@CCNY 
Agree completely.

@Lauren Ford 

You’re dating yourself!

@Steve L 

I think commenting on a crossword puzzle is a good indicator of being in the elderly demographic.

@Mr Dave 

You’re not supposed to say that out loud!

@Mr Dave 

Well, Lucy Dacus knows something about crosswords. She's not elderly.

@John Carson 
Strands #358
“Step to it”
🔵🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵🔵🟡
Simple enough to solve, though i enjoyed the solutions. 

When you say you're presented with a new game, do you men the same game, but unsolved or a totally different game?

@Vaer 

Same game unsolved.  This used to be the case with Connections (and probably Wordle) which at first did not attach to the login.  I checked and Strands does seem to still be free.

@John Carson 

Strands #358
“Step to it”
🔵🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵🟡🔵

One of the answers was the name of our favorite cat.


It does seem like Strands is an orphan game, no archive, no stats, no column.

@John Carson 

Strands #358
“Step to it”
🔵🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵🔵🟡

Some fun themers today! Has this constructor graced us with a puzzle before? 

As for the puzzle refresh, I have commented before that Strands does not retain one's progress at all -- not just to the login (meaning ability to play across devices and at asynchronous times) but even during the session. 

So if you back out of the puzzle, or even if the screen auto-reloads as often happens in a browser, the puzzle resets. To my recollection, it's unique to this puzzle -- and I'm not a fan, lol. When it happens to me, I give up and wait for another day. It's just not that interesting to redo a word search!

@G They should hire us as testers! I just opened today's game on a different machine, entered the spanner and then closed the tab (Chrome on Win10). Reopened the game and my spanner entry was there. But the behavior may be different on different platforms. Not sure what browser you use but I've used Chrome's autorefresh feature for some websites which will sometimes give me an unexpected refresh. Today's constructor is a veteran: https://www.monicochavez.com/

@John Carson 

Ooh, they should! As it is, I just hope there's at least one person on the Strands product team who checks here for user feedback... I only email them rarely; like replaying the game, it's just not that convenient(!).

Chrome on Android here. My habit is to use the back function to exit games, and with Strands it clears the board every time. I find it fascinating that your session was retained on the desktop! I'll have to check it out next time. 

(Also Chrome on Win10! Sadly my laptop is end-of-life as it's not eligible to upgrade the OS any more...)

@John Carson 

My partner is a committed Linux guy: he boots into Windows once a year to do his taxes. 😂 

I really love my laptop, geeky as that is! Nice form factor. When I first got it, my partner helped me install a shell to run a virtual Mac. Worked great until the emulator didn't update to support a Mac OS upgrade... 

I remember Y2K: got a lot of work from companies rushing to get off DOS and into Windows, lol. Now I'm one of the ones on the receiving end! Thanks for letting me know I'm not alone! 😁

@Rich in Atlanta As threatened - a Wednesday from November 6, 1991 by Robert Katz. Don't recall seeing another one like this. Three 15 letter theme answers: "Big names in TV" ABCCBSNBCANDCNN "Big names in educ." UCLAMITNYUANDBU "Big names in intl. orgs." NATOOASUNANDEEC Here's that Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=11/6/1991&g=20&d=A I'm done. ...

@Rich in Atlanta

 I didn't have that one on my list of Robert Katz's puzzles to do, but now I'll try it. I haven't looked at your answers,(He was my cousin, uncredited in the Maleska era.) I've only done two so far, and they're quite different from those we see today. Definitely not as interesting or theme-y. But that was only two of them.

@suejean 

Its interesting because my solve took longer than usual - which must mean the puzzle was on the tough side - but it didn't *feel* tough: which in turn may mean it was really well constructed, at least as I perceived it.
@Kristopher recent episode of Abbott Elementary deals with this topic. Common in public school systems where standardized test scores are currency for resources.

@Kristopher 

Not any kind of stretch at all.  Just an expression—or perhaps a concept—you’re unaware of or unfamiliar with.

@Kristopher 
Aah - teaching to the test brings back so many memories.  It wasn't just the test material, it was also the use of psychological manipulation.
Very often there would be 4 or 5 A's or B's or C's etc. in a row and my students would think, "That couldn't be right," and would change their answers.  I had to assure them that their answers could remain because those choices didn't appear again for a while.

I've almost come to the conclusion that spelling is entirely random, and that it's impossible to congregate enough English language "rules" to guarantee a single plural for a noun.

I mean, look at English spelling:

knife (silent k)
gnome (silent g)
prerogative (pronounce "per...")
surprise (sometimes silent first r)
their (remember "i before e, except after c"...just it doesn't 
      work for one of the most common words.)

I'm sure the wordsmiths here can come up with battalions of examples.

It seems to me that battles over the "correct" spelling is akin to arguments about how many angels can dance on the head of a pin.

@KadyRN

When I was a student, I don't think I ever asked if something was going to be on the test.  I expected myself to know everything that happened in the class, everything written in the reading assignments, whether the teacher had mentioned it or not.  

I remember occasionally asking the prof a question about an edge topic in the later part of a chemistry chapter, and he's say, "we can talk about it, but there's no way I'm going to ask anything about that".

My feeling was that I was there to get an education, not a grade.

I realize I'm reeking with self-satisfied virtue signaling, but I think we've lost even the sense of what a good education really is.

@Francis 

A big part of this middle-class NYC kid's, (Ivy League), education in the late 1950s was everything that happened outside of class and library.

Like learning the names of the neighborhoods my prep-schooled classmates came from. (Grosse Point, Shaker Heights, etc.)

Understanding that the "Gentleman's C" was the academic norm at many of the fraternities.
(That could be different today or maybe it's just grade inflation.)

That "The Two Cultures" by C.P. Snow struck very close to home for us Engineering students. 

The whole first-time-away-from-home social scene.  Even in the days of in loco parentis.

The spring-break Glee Club tour of the segregated South just as the sit-in movement was beginning.  One highlight in an otherwise depressing week: Singing at the National Cathedral on Easter Sunday.

@KadyRN 

Passed my license exam 50 years ago this coming May or June; decades before NCLEX; don't remember the questions, but do remember the two days away from home, with three tests one day and two the next, each at least two hours. Remember taking a lunch break at someone's hotel room, picking up somebody's review book and randomly looking at a question—it turned out to be on the next test!

But we weren't taught for the test. We were taught the basics, taught some of the skills, and taught how to find information we did not yet know. We had enough to get by, but were expected to become proficient and refine our skills through practice, to learn from our colleagues, and hopefully get to a point where we were the one helping the new nurses to develop their skills.

Worked in a variety of roles from 1975 to 2013.
